articles.title: Wales' New Green Farming Plan After Brexit
articles.summary: Wales has started a new plan to help farmers after leaving the EU. This plan gives money to farms that do things to help the environment, like taking care of land and using fewer chemicals. Farmers must manage at least 10% of their land as a habitat to join. Some farmers are happy, but others, like dairy farmers, find it hard because their land might not qualify. There were protests before because people thought the plan was not good, but after talks, it is now better. The government says this is a big moment for Wales. Farms used to get money from the EU based on how much land they had, but now they get paid for being green. The plan has rules like keeping hedges healthy and learning about sustainable farming online. More money is available for farms that do extra environmental work. People hope many farmers will join to make the countryside better.

articles.title: Exercise Makes You Burn More Energy All Day
articles.summary: A new study shows that when you exercise, your body uses more energy throughout the whole day without cutting back on other important tasks. Scientists from Virginia Tech and other universities worked together to learn about how physical activity affects our energy budget, which is like how our body spends energy on different jobs. They studied 75 people of different ages and activity levels, from not very active to ultra-runners. The participants wore sensors to track movement and drank special water to measure calories burned. The results found that moving more leads to burning more calories, and the body doesn't reduce energy used for things like breathing or keeping warm. This means exercise helps you use extra energy without your body canceling it out, which is good news for staying healthy.

articles.title: A Bubbly Space Crash: The Champagne Cluster
articles.summary: Astronomers found a special group of galaxies called the Champagne Cluster. It looks like bubbles and was discovered on New Year's Eve in 2020. This cluster is actually two groups of galaxies crashing into each other. The hot gas from the crash is shown in purple in pictures from a space telescope. The gas is stretched out, which tells scientists it's a collision. There are also two bunches of galaxies, one above and one below, showing the two groups. The hot gas and dark matter, which we can't see, make up most of the mass in this cluster. Scientists use telescopes on Earth to take pictures in colors like red, green, and blue. They compare what they see with computer games to guess how the crash happened. This helps them learn about dark matter in space.

articles.title: Mystery of Women in a Medieval Cemetery
articles.summary: Archaeologists in Wales are trying to solve a mystery about women buried in a medieval cemetery. They found 58 skeletons from the 6th or 7th century, and almost all are women. The team discovered a small building outline, beads, and other items that show the women might have been part of a religious community. The graves are shallow and cut into rock, and people wanted to be buried near the building, sometimes sharing graves. This helps us learn about life long ago and who these women were.

articles.title: How a Missing Protein Makes Our Immune System Weaker as We Age
articles.summary: As people get older, their immune system can become weaker, making it harder to fight off sickness. Scientists have found that a protein called platelet factor 4 is important for keeping our immune system strong. This protein helps control special cells in our bone marrow called blood stem cells, which make all the cells in our blood and immune system. When we are young, platelet factor 4 tells these stem cells when to divide and make new cells. But as we age, our bodies produce less of this protein. Without enough platelet factor 4, the stem cells divide too much and can get damaged, leading to more health problems like infections or cancer. In experiments with mice, scientists showed that adding back platelet factor 4 to older cells helped reverse some signs of aging, making them act like younger cells again. This discovery could lead to new treatments to help older people stay healthier by boosting their immune systems.

articles.title: How Drinking a Little Alcohol Can Increase Mouth Cancer Risk
articles.summary: A new study from India shows that drinking even a small amount of alcohol every day, like one drink, can raise the risk of getting mouth cancer by 50%. Mouth cancer is a serious disease that affects the inside of the cheeks and lips, and it is very common in India, causing many deaths each year. The study found that people who drink alcohol and also chew tobacco have an even higher risk, with this combination possibly causing over half of all mouth cancer cases in the country. Researchers looked at thousands of people, some with cancer and some without, to learn about their drinking and tobacco habits. They discovered that locally made alcoholic drinks, often drunk in rural areas, are especially risky. This research helps us understand why it's important to be careful with alcohol and tobacco to stay healthy.
